awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Low Temperature Cofired Multilayer Ceramic Power Transformers Incorporating Base Metallization Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to a wide range of electronics as to include power supplies, inverters point-of-load (POL) power devices, voltage isolators and voltage sensors.  The high thermal operation that is EMI/RFI immune and very rad hard enables completely new electronics design solutions for medical, space, defense, and energy exploration.  This new technology proposed will be ideal for distributed POL solutions for commercial solar energy, high performance adaptors and converters for mobile/portable electronics, robotic integrated subcompact power supplies.  The success will also open up new capabilities for agencies such as NASA, and commercial space companies to integrate a new subcompact solution for converting mains bus power to all of the subsystems that is far more radiation and high temperature tolerant than anything ever previously available.   This is of particular interest to the SmallSat/CubeSat (miniaturized satellite) community.  There will also be spin-off benefits to manufacturing of higher performance actuators and transducer devices that will see significant decreased costs through use of significantly less expensive copper materials.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project will address the challenge of enabling high power/high performance ceramic transformers that replaces conventional magnetics.  Many electronics applications can benefit from replacing magnetic transformer with ceramics. Advantages include large increase in safe operating temperatures, drastically reducing the electromagnetic/radio frequency interference (EMI/RFI) issues, and reducing the size/weight. At present, no such transformers exist.  Any solution will require multilayer construction; however, for transformers this introduces several difficult and unsolved challenges in electronics process engineering that are not issues for multilayer ceramic capacitors, piezoelectric actuators and piezoelectric sensors manufacture.  These new challenges include that the multilayer construction must now enable individual poling of each layer; because transformer devices must operate at resonance they now generate much greater levels of thermal energy requiring drastically improved thermal management (electrode electrical/thermal conduction); also requires replacing soft ceramic with low loss hard ceramic. Copper introduces very superior properties in electrical/thermal conduction but requires  significantly lower process temperatures that will be challenging to achieve for sintered hard ceramic but offers enormous pay-off with success. The research will investigate the promising approach of a new low temperature process that uses new doping chemistries and advantageous copper electroding.

One of the most commonplace electrical components used in the modern world is the electromagnetic transformer (EMT).  Consisting of a magnetic core, primary winding, and secondary winding, the common EMT provides critical electrical isolation to prevent ground loops and surge throughputs and provides for voltage level shifting from its primary side to its secondary side.  Assuming there are no losses involved in this process, one can simply change the voltage level by changing the number of windings on either side. Due to the basic physics of electromagnetic transformers (EMT’s) these devices are usually heavy and bulky.  They are also very challenging and costly to miniaturize.  There has been some progress with planar magnetics but these are still in the milliwatt range and far from useful as yet. 

The main goal of the proposed research is to greatly improve user options in the transformer device market, which is entirely occupied by magnetics. The technological improvements being investigated would open up many of these markets to our smaller/lighter piezoceramics technology. Until now, the major drawback for the piezoelectric transformers technology is their cost and limited power handling. This is due to the fact that there has not been a viable low cost high performance alternative to expensive metallization of high power density multilayer ceramic transformers. Piezoceramic transformers (PT) require the use of hard-piezoelectric ceramics (hard-piezoceramics), where the ceramic structure forms at high temperatures (>1200?C). To maximize the power in compact volumes, devices should be designed in multilayer form, where piezoceramic and metal layers are stacked alternatively on top of each other. However, multilayer structure brings the use of large amounts of metal, which is pretty much limited to platinum (Pt) due to high processing temperatures of hard-piezoceramics. Since, power is proportional to the layer count and therefore to the amount of the electrode used, the use of precious metals can significantly increase the production cost. Hence, hard-piezoceramic compositions need to be modified in such a way that the processing (sintering) temperature is lowered to allow the use of cheaper and electrically and thermally well-performing metals/alloys and preferably base-metal electrodes such as silver (Ag)/silver-palladium (Ag-Pd) and copper (Cu) or nickel (Ni). Nonetheless, use of such metals in multilayer applications demands quite challenging consideration of engineering and science principles. Hard-PZT is almost the most utilized piezoceramic compared to other hard-piezoceramics. Unfortunately, Ni is not chemically compatible with hard-PZT but Cu seems to be very promising considering the previous results on Cu co-fired multilayer piezoceramics with soft-PZT. Moreover, there have been investigations on hard-PZT compositions with low sintering temperatures but they were not practically applied to co-fired multilayer PT’s.

This program investigated how to substantially lower the process temperatures for a typical hard-PZT composition and allow the use of less expensive electrode materials. To realize these goals; modified hard-PZT piezoceramic compositions with low sintering temperatures (≤1000?C) were developed and demonstrated in multilayer PT with Ag/Pd co-fired electrodes with low Pd contents (i.e. 90/10 and 95/5) and high efficiencies, feasibility of Cu co-firing was investigated, and Cu co-fired multilayer PT was prototyped. Our efforts included typical multilayer prototyping for overall and ambient sintering for Ag/Pd co-fired PT, and reducing atmosphere sintering for Cu co-firing feasibility investigations and Cu co-fired PT prototypes.
